p: KEYV is distributed on the east coast of North America from Florida, where the virus was firstly discovered in 1964 from Aedes atlanticus in Keystone [ 151], up to Maryland in the north and Texas in the west. Vertebrate hosts seem to be mammals such as squirrels, raccoons, and white-tailed deer [ 152, 153, 154], while the main insect vectors are mosquitoes such as Aedes atlanticus [ 155], various Aedes spp. (e.g., vexans, tiseriatus, taeniorhynchus, infirmatus, canadensis), and some Culex spp. [ 156]. In humans, antibodies against KEYV have been repeatedly detected [ 157], and the virus itself was isolated from individuals showing clinical symptoms such as fever and rash [ 158].
